section.para:
A is a data structure consisting of a series of space-separated letters, numerals, or underscores. For example,
a b c
is a containing three elements, a, b, and c.
The -specific primitives are located in the chaos/preprocessor/string subdirectory.

, unlike other data structures, have a restricted domain of possible element values. Each element must be a single letter (from a to z or from A to Z), a numeral (from 0 to 9), or an underscore (_). Any other character is invalid, and any operation that inserts an invalid character invalidates the . The invocation of an algorithm on an invalid is undefined and will likely cause catastrophic failure.

Note that it is safe to use the core operations defined in with invalid provided that the invalid element is never the first element of the . For example,
(a xyz b) // a (a xyz b) // xyz b
(xyz b) // invalid
This allowance makes it possible to reuse the data type in the creation of, for example, and extensible string data type. However, such use requires extreme care.

section.id: Using Strings as Generic Data Structures

In C (prior to C99) and C++, there is no such thing as a nil . However, the special value () can be used to indicate a nil to the core operations defined in --thus allowing the generic algorithms to operate on nil in a temporal fashion. The other -specific primitives, on the other hand, do not recognize (). Therefore, a "would-be" nil result from a -specific primitive is undefined. The result of generic algorithm that yields a nil is well-defined provided that it is used only as a --meaning that it can be passed to other generic algorithms, etc.--or used by the core operations in after the type prefix is stripped. For example,
( (3, () a b c), () x y ) // () x y
In C99, nil are well-defined as "nothing", which is accepted as the representation of nil by all primitives.
